turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: Am I? Maybe to a schoolboy's eye. People who know about the human heart, though, mebbe they'd say, Bill over here, he gives his honey love, and she pays him back with pity  the basest coin there is.

turns.speaker: AUDREY
turns.text: Stop it, Bill!

turns.speaker: AUDREY
turns.text: Barton, I'm afraid it's not a good time-

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: Drown all those rascals...

turns.speaker: AUDREY
turns.text: All right Barton, I'll see if I can slip away-

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: Who is that?! Gaddamn voices come into the house... sons of bitches...

turns.speaker: AUDREY
turns.text: I'll try to slip out. If he quiets down, passes out... I'm afraid he thinks  well, he said you were a buffoon, Barton. He becomes irrational

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: Hesh up! Be still now! DROWN 'EM! DROWN 'EM! DROWN 

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: How d'ya like your room!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Who is this?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Chet!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Who?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Chet! From downstairs!

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: ...Hello.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Garland, it's me.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I write.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Oh yeah? What kind of write?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well as a matter of fact, I write for the pictures.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No, I  I didn't mean to sound 

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: What DID you mean?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I  I've got respect for  for working guys, like you 

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: How long you been up there, Fink?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: A week, eight, nine days 

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Ever talk to him?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Once or twice. His name is Charlie Meadows.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Yeah, he's funny that way.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...No. I never saw him with anyone else.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: So. You talked to Mundt, what about?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Nothing, really. Said he was in the insurance business.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well that's what he said.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: What else?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: He... I'm trying to think... Nothing, really... He... He said he liked Jack Oakie pictures.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Could you come back later?  It's just...  too hot... My head is killing me.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: All right, forget the heads. Where's Mundt, Fink?

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: W.P. Mayhew? The writer?

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: Just Bill, please.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Sir, I'm flattered that you even recognize my name. My God, I had no idea you were in Hollywood.

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: All of us undomesticated writers eventually make their way out here to the Great Salt Lick. Mebbe that's why I allus have such a powerful thrust.

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: ...A little social lubricant, Mistuh Fink?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: It's still a little early for me.

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: So be it.

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: ...Still, I must say. I haven't felt peace like this since the grand productive days. Don't you find it so, Barton? Ain't writin' peace?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well... actually, no Bill...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...No, I've always found that writing comes from a great inner pain. Maybe it's a pain that comes from a realization that one must do something for one's fellow man  to help somehow to ease his suffering.  Maybe it's a personal pain. At any rate, I don't believe good work is possible without it.

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: Mmm. Wal, me, I just enjoy maikn' things up. Yessir. Escape... It's when I can't write, can't escape m'self, that I want to tear m'head off and run screamin' down the street with m'balls in a fruitpickers pail. Mm...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Look, maybe it's none of my business, but a man with your talent  don't you think your first obligation would be to your gift? Shouldn't you be doing whatever you have to do to work again?

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: And what would that be, son?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I don't know exactly. But I do know what you're doing with that drink. You're cutting yourself off from your gift, and from me and Audrey, and from your fellow man, and from everything your art is about.

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: No son, thisahere moonshine's got nothin' to do with shuttin' folks out. No, I'm usin' it to build somethin'.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: I'm buildin' a levee. Gulp by gulp, brick by brick. Raisin' up a levee to keep that ragin' river of manure from lappin' at m'door.

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: I'll jus' walk on down to the Pacific, and from there I'll... improvise.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm sorry, I just feel like I know I shouldn't ask, I just need some kind of help, I just, I have a deadline tomorrow-

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: I said drown 'em all! Who is that?

turns.speaker: MAYHEW
turns.text: Goddamn voices... DROWN 'EM!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I need help, Audrey.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm a writer, Mr. Geisler. Ted Okum said I should drop by morning to see you about the 

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Ever act?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Huh? No, I'm 

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: We need Indians for a Norman Steele western.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm a writer. Ted O 

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Think about it, Fink. Writers come and go; we always need Indians.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm a writer. Ted Okum said you're producing this Wallace Beery picture I'm working on.

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: What!?  Ted Okum doesn't know shit. They've assigned me enough pictures for a goddamn year. What Ted Okum doesn't know you could almost squeeze into the Hollywood Bowl.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Then who should I talk to?

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Don't worry about it. It's just a B picture. I bring it in on budget, they'll book it without even screening it. Life is too short.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: But Lipnik said he wanted to look at the script, see something by the end of the week.

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Sure he did. And he forgot about it before your ass left his sofa.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Okay. I'm just having trouble getting started. It's funny, I'm blocked up. I feel like I need some kind of indication of... what's expected 

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Wallace Beery. Wrestling picture. What do you need, a road map?

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: ...Look, you're confused? You need guidance? Talk to another writer.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Wuddya got for me  what the hell happened to your face?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Nothing. It's just a mosquito bite.

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Like hell it is; there are no mosquitos in Los Angeles. Mosquitos breed in swamps  this is a desert town. Wuddya got for me?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well I...

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: On the Beery picture! Where are we? Wuddya got?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, to tell you the truth, I'm having some trouble getting started

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Getting STARTED! Christ Jesus! Started?!  You mean you don't have ANYthing?!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well not much.

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: What do you think this is? HAMLET? GONE WITH THE WIND? RUGGLES OF RED GAP? It's a goddamn B picture! Big men in tights! You know the drill!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm afraid I don't really understand that genre. maybe that's the prob-

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Understand shit! I though you were gonna consult another writer on this!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, I've talked to Bill Mayhew-

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Bill Mayhew! Some help! The guy's a souse!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: He's a great writer 

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: A souse!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: You don't understand. He's in pain, because he can't write-

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Souse! Souse! He manages to write his name on the back of his paycheck every week!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: But... I thought no one cared about this picture.

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: You thought! Where'd you get THAT from?  You thought! I don't know what the hell you said to Lipnik, but the sonofabitch LIKES you! You understand that, Fink? He LIKES you! He's taken an interest. NEVER make Lipnik like you. NEVER!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I don't understand-

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Are you deaf, he LIKES you! He's taken an interest! What the hell did you say to him?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I didn't say anything-

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Well he's taken an interest!  That means he'll make your life hell, which I could care less about, but since I drew the short straw to supervise this turkey, he's gonna be all over me too! Fat-assed sonofabitch called me yesterday to ask how it's going  don't worry, I covered for you. Told him you were making progress and we were all very excited. I told him it was great, so now MY ass is on the line.  He wants you to tell him all about it tomorrow.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I can't write anything by tomorrow.

turns.speaker: GEISLER
turns.text: Who said write? Jesus, Jack can't read.  You gotta TELL it to him-tell him SOMEthing for Chrissake.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well what do I tell him?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I thought you were going to join us. Jesus, Garland, you left me alone with those people.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Don't panic, I'll join you in a minute.  What's you think of Richard and Poppy?

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: We have to talk a little business. I've just been on the phone to Los Angeles.  Barton, Capitol Pictures wants to put you under contract. They've offered you a thousand dollars a week. I think I can get them to go as high as two.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: To do what?

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: What do you do far a living?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm not sure anymore. I guess I try to make a difference.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Fair enough. No pressure here, Barton, because I respect you, but let me point out a couple of things. One, here you make a difference to five hundred fifty people a night  if the show sells out.  Eighty five million people go to the pictures every week.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: To see pap.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Yes, generally, to see pap. However, point number two: A brief tenure in Hollywood could support you through the writing of any number of plays.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I don't know, Garland; my place is here right now. I feel I'm on the brink of success-

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: I'd say you're already enjoying some.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...I guess I'm sprouting off again. But I am certain of this, Garland: I'm capable of more good work. Maybe better work than I did in Choirs. It just doesn't seem to me that Los Angeles is the place to lead the life of mind.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Okay Barton, you're the artist, I'm just the ten percenter. You decide what you want and I'll make it happen. I'm only asking that your decision be informed by a little realism  if I can use that word and Hollywood in the same breath.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: ...Look, they love you, kid  everybody does. You see Caven's review in the Herald?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No, what did it say?

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Take my copy. You're the toast of Broadway and you have the opportunity to redeem that for a little cash  strike that, a lot of cash.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Barton? What time is it? Are you all right?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah, I'm fine, Garland  I have to talk to you. I'm calling long distance.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: ...What is it Barton? Are you okay?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm fine, garland, but I have to talk with you.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Go ahead, son.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: It's about what I'm writing, Garland. It's really... I think it's really big.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: What do you mean, Barton?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Not big in the sense of large  although it's that too. I mean important. This may be the most IMPORTANT work I've done.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Well, I'm... glad to hear that 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Very important, Garland. I just thought you should know that. Whatever happens.

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: ...That's fine.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Have you read the Bible, Garland?

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: ...Barton, is everything okay?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yes... Isn't it?

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Well, I'm just asking. You sound a little 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Sound a little what?

turns.speaker: GARLAND
turns.text: Well, you just... sound a little

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Neighbor, I'd feel better about the damned inconvenience if you'd let me buy you a drink.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: That's all right, really, thank you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: All right, hell, you trying to work and me carrying on in there. Look, the liquor's good, wuddya say?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ... You got a glass? It's the least I can do.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Okay... a quick one, sure...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah, just a nip. I feel like hell, all the carryings-on next door.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: That's okay, I assure you. It's just that I was trying to work 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What kind of work do you do, Barton, if you don't mind my asking?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, I'm a writer, actually.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You don't say. That's a tough racket. My hat's off to anyone who can make a go of it. Damned interesting work, I'd imagine.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Can be. Not easy, but 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Damned difficult, I'd imagine.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: And what's your line, Mr. Meadows?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hell no! Call me Charlie. Well Barton, you might say I sell peace of mind. Insurance is my game  door-to-door, human contact, still the only way to move merchandise.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...In spite of what you might think from tonight, I'm pretty good at it.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Doesn't surprise me at all.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hell yes. Because I believe in it. Fire, theft, and casualty are not things that only happen to other people  that's what I tell 'em. Writing doesn't work out, you might want to look into it. Providing for basic human need  a fella could do worse.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Thanks, I'll keep it in mind.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What kind of scribbler are you  newspaperman did you say?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No, I'm actually writing for the pictures now 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Pictures! Jesus!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Is the egg showing or what?!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: That's okay; actually I am just starting out in the movies  though I was pretty well established in New York, some renown there,

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Oh, it's an exciting time then. I'm not the best-read mug on the planet, so I guess it's no surprise I didn't recognize your name. Jesus, I feel like a heel.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: That's okay, Charlie. I'm a playwright. My shows've only played New York. Last one got a hell of a write-up in the Herald. I guess that's why they wanted me here.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hell, why not? Everyone wants quality. What kind of venue, that is to say, thematically, uh...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: What do I write about?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Caught me trying to be fancy! Yeah, that's it, Bart.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, that's a good question. Strange as it may seem, Charlie, I guess I write about people like you. The average working stiff. The common man.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Well ain't that a kick in the head!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah, I guess it is. But in a way, that's exactly the point. There's a few people in New York  hopefully our numbers are growing  who feel we have an opportunity now to forge something real out of everyday experience, create a theater for the masses that's based on a few simple truths  not on some shopworn abstractions about drama that doesn't hold true today, if they ever did...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...I don't guess this means much to you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hell, I could tell you some stories

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: And that's the point, that we all have stories. The hopes and dreams of the common man are as noble as those of any king. It's the stuff of life  why shouldn't it be the stuff of theater?  Goddamnit, why should that be a hard pill to swallow? Don't call it new theater, Charlie; call it real theater. Call it our theater.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I can see you feel pretty strongly about it.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, I don't mean to get up on my high horse, but why shouldn't we look at ourselves up there?  Who cares about the Fifth Earl of Bastrop and Lady Higginbottom and  and  and who killed Nigel Grinch-Gibbons?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I can feel my butt getting sore already.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Exactly, Charlie! You understand what I'm saying  a lot more than some of these literary types. Because you're a real man!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: And I could tell you some stories 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Sure you could!  And yet many writers do everything in their power to insulate themselves from the common man  from where they live, from where they trade, from where they fight and love and converse and  and  and... so naturally their work suffers, and regresses into empty formalism and  well, I'm spouting off again, but to put it in your language, the theater becomes as phony as a three dollar bill.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah, I guess that's tragedy right there.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Frequently played, seldom remarked.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: You're all right, Charlie. I'm glad you stopped by. I'm sorry if  well I know I sometimes run on.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hell no! Jesus, I'm the kind of guy, I'll let you know if I'm bored. I find it all pretty damned interesting. I'm the kind schmoe who's generally interested in the other guy's point of view.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, we've got something in common then.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Sure, sure Charlie, you can help by just being yourself.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Well, I can tell you some stories 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...And look, I'm sorry as hell about the interruption. Too much revelry late at night, you forget there are other people in the world.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: See you, Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Howdy, neighbor.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Charlie. How are you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Jesus, I hope I'm not interrupting you again. I heard you walking around in here.  Figured I'd drop by.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah, come in Charlie. Hadn't really gotten started yet  what happened to your ear?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah. An ear infection, chronic thing.  Goes away for a while, but it always comes back. Gotta put cotton in it to staunch the flow of pus. Don't worry, it's not contagious.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Seen a doctor?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Ah, doctors. What's he gonna tell me?  Can't trade my head in for a new one.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No, I guess you're stuck with the one you've got. Have a seat.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Thanks, I'd invite you over to my place, but it's a goddamn mess. You married, Bart?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I myself have yet to be lassoed.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Got a sweetheart?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No... I guess it's something about my work. I get so worked up over it, I don't know; I don't really have a lot of attention left over, so it would be a little unfair...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah, the ladies do ask for attention. In my experience, they pretend to give it, but it's generally a smoke- screen for demanding it back  with interest. How about family, Bart? How're you fixed in that department?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: My folks live in Brooklyn, with my uncle.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Mine have passed on. It's just the three of us now...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...What's the expression  me myself and I.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Sure, that's tough, but in a sense, we're all alone in this world aren't we Charlie?  I'm often surrounded by family and friends, but...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...It was taken by one of my policy holders. They're more than just customers to me, Barton.  They really appreciate what I have to offer them. Ya see, her hubby was out of town at the time 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: You know, in a way, I envy you Charlie.  Your daily routine  you know what's expected. You know the drill. My job is to plumb the depths, so to speak, dredge something up from inside, something honest. There's no road map for that territory...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...This must be boring you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Not at all. It's damned interesting.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Probably sounds a little grand coming from someone who's writing a wrestling picture for Wallace Beery.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Beery! You got no beef there! He's good.  Hell of an actor  though, for my money, you can't beat Jack Oakie. A stitch, Oakie. Funny stuff, funny stuff. But don't get me wrong  Beery, a wrestling picture, that could be a pip. Wrestled some myself back in school. I guess you know the basic moves.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Nope, never watched any. I'm not that interested in the act itself 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Okay, but hell, you should know what it is. I can show you in about thirty seconds.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...You're a little out of your weight class, but just for purposes of demonstration 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: That's all right, really 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Not a bit of it, compadre! Easiest thing in the world! You just get down on your knees to my left, slap your right hand here...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...All right now, when I say "Ready... wrestle!"  you try and pin me, and I try and pin you. That's the whole game. Got it?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Yeah, okay.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Ready... wrestle!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: It's okay, it's okay.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Well, that's all that wrestling is. Except usually there's more grunting and squirming before the pin. Well, it's your first time. And you're out of your weight class.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I hope these are your shoes.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Hi, Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Because that would mean they gave you mine.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah, as a matter of fact they did. Come on in.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Jesus, what a day I've had. Ever had one of those days?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Seems like nothing but, lately.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Jesus, what a day. Felt like I couldn't've sold ice water in the Sahara. Jesus. Okay, so you don't want insurance, so okay, that's your loss. But God, people can be rude. Feel like I have to talk to a normal person like just to restore a little of my...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, my pleasure. I could use a little lift myself.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: A little lift, yeah...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Did I say rude? People can be goddamn cruel. Especially some of their housewives. Okay, so I've got a weight problem. That's my cross to bear. I dunno...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well it's... it's a defense mechanism.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Defense against what? Insurance? Something they need? Something they should be thanking me for offering? A little peace of mind?...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Listen to me belly-achin'. As if my problems amounted to a hill of beans. How goes the life of the mind?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, it's been better. I can't seem to get going on this thing. That one idea, the one that lets you get started  I still haven't gotten it. Maybe I only had one idea in me  my play. Maybe once that was done, I was done being a writer.  Christ, I feel like a fraud, sitting here staring at this paper.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Those two love-birds next door drivin' you nuts?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: How did you know about that?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Know about it? I can practically see how they're doin' it. Brother, I wish I had a piece of that.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah, but 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Seems like I hear everything that goes on in this dump. Pipes or somethin'. I'm just glad I don't have to ply MY trade in the wee-wee hours.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Ah, you'll lick this picture business, believe me. You've got a head on your shoulders. What is it they say? Where there's a head, there's a hope?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Where there's life there's hope.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: And there's hope for you too, Charlie. Tomorrow I bet you sell a half-dozen policies.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Thanks, brother. But the fact is, I gotta pull up stakes temporarily.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: You're leaving?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: In a few days. Out to your stompin' grounds as a matter of fact  New York City. Things have gotten all balled up at the Head Office.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm truly sorry to hear that, Charlie. I'll miss you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Well hell, buddy, don't pull a long face!  This is still home for me  I keep my room, and I'll be back sooner or later...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Your room does that too?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I guess the heat's sweating off the wallpaper.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What a dump...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...I guess it seems pathetic to a guy like you.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Well it's pathetic, isn't it? I mean to a guy from New York.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: This kind of heat. It's pathetic.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, I guess you pick your poison.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: So they say.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Don't pick up and leave without saying goodbye.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Course not, compadre. You'll see me again.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Can I come in?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No!... I'm fine. Thank you.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Are you sure 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No... no...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Barton. Are you all right?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No... Can I come in?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Why don't we go to your room-

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Charlie, I'm in trouble. You've gotta help me.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Get a grip on yourself, brother. Whatever the problem is, we'll sort it out.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Charlie, I'm in trouble  something horrible's happened  I've gotta call the police...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Will you stay with me till they get here?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't worry about it, Barton. We can sort it-

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Jesus, Barton, what the hell is this?  What're we gonna do?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I've gotta call the police  or you could call for me 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hold on 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: You gotta believe me 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hold on 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I didn't do this, I did NOT do this

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hold on. Stop. Take a deep breath. Tell me what happened.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I don't know! I woke up, she was... God, you gotta believe me!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I believe you, brother, but this don't look good.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: We gotta call the police 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hold on. I said hold on, so hold on.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What do you think happened?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I don't know!  Maybe it was her... boyfriend. I passed out. I don't know.  Won't the police be able to 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Stop with the police! Wake up, friend! This does not look good! They hang people for this!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: But I didn't do it  don't you believe me?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I believe you  I KNOW you. But why should the police?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Jesus... They can tell that...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: They GOTTA believe me, Charlie! They gotta have mercy!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You're in pictures, Barton. Even if you got cleared eventually, this would ruin you.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Uh-huh... Where's Audrey?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: She's dead, Barton! If that was her name.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Jesus... You're leaving.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Have to, old timer. Just for a while.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Jesus, Charlie, I...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Everything's okay, believe me. I know it's rough mentally, but everything's taken care of.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Charlie! I've got no one else here! You're the only person I know in Los Angeles...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It's okay... It's okay...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Charlie, I feel like I'm going crazy  like I'm losing my mind. I don't know what to do... I didn't do it, believe me. I'm sure of that, Charlie. I just...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...I just don't know what... to do

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You gotta get a grip on, brother. You gotta just carry on  just for a few days, till I get back. Try and stay here, keep your door locked. Don't talk to anyone. We just gotta keep our heads and we'll figure it out.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah, but Charlie 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Dammit, don't argue with me. You asked me to believe you  well I do. Now don't argue with me.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Sure, Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Funny, huh, when everything that's important to a guy, everything he wants to keep from a lifetime  when he can fit it into a little box like that. I guess... I guess it's kind of pathetic.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: It's more than I've got.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Well, keep it for me. Maybe it'll bring you good luck. Yeah, it'll help you finish your script. You'll think about me...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: You'll be back?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't worry about that, compadre. I'll be back.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...Don't look at me like that, neighbor.  It's just me  Charlie.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I hear it's Mundt. Madman Mundt.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: But Charlie  why me? Why 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Because you DON'T LISTEN!

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: ...Where did we put him?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm at the Earle.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Never heard of it. Let's move him to the Grand, or the Wilshire, or hell, he can stay at my place.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Thanks, but I wanted a place that was less...

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Less Hollywood?  Sure, say it, it's not a dirty word. Sat whatever the hell you want. The writer is king here at Capitol Pictures. You don't believe me, take a look at your paycheck at the end of every week  that's what we think of the writer.  ...so what kind of pictures does he like?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: To be honest, I don't go to the pictures much, Mr. Lipnik 

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: That's okay, that's okay, that's okay  that's just fine. You probably just walked in here thinking that was going to be a handicap, thinking we wanted people who knew something about the medium, maybe even thinking there was all kind of technical mumbo- jumbo to learn. You were dead wrong. We're only interested in one thing: Can you tell a story, Bart?  Can you make us laugh, can you make us cry, can you make us wanna break out in joyous song? Is that more than one thing? Okay.  The point is, I run this dump and I don't know the technical mumbo-jumbo. Why do I run it? I've got horse-sense, goddamnit. Showmanship. And also, and I hope Lou told you this, I bigger and meaner than any other kike in this town. Did you tell him that, Lou? And I don't mean my dick's bigger than yours, it's not a sexual thing  although, you're the writer, you would know more about that. Coffee?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Yes, thank you.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Lou.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: ...Well Bart, which is it? Orphan? Dame?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Both maybe?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah... rye whiskey?

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Boy! You writers! Work hard, play hard!  That's what I hear, anyway...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...It's a tenement building. On the Lower East Side...

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Great! He's poor, this wrestler! He's had to struggle!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: And then... well...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Can I be honest, Mr. Lipnik?

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: CAN you?  You damn well better be. Jesus, if I hadn't been honest in my business dealings  well, of course, you can't always be honest, not with the sharks swimming around this town  but if you're a writer, you don't think about those things  if I'd been totally honest, I wouldn't be within a mile of this pool  unless I was cleaning it. But that's no reason for you not to be. Honest, I mean.  Not cleaning the pool.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I  Mr. Lipnik 

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: KISS THIS MAN'S FEET!!

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Mr. Lipnik, I 

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: I apologize, Barton.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: No no, Mr. Breeze has actually been a great help 

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: You don't have to cover for him. It's noble of you, but these things happen in business.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Mr. Lipnik, I really would feel much better if you could reconsider 

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Ah, forget it, kid. I want you to pull this out of your head. If that sonofabitch wouldn't apologize to you, goddammit, I will. I respect your artistry and your methods, and if you can't fill us in yet, well hell, we should be kissing your feet for your fine efforts.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Fink.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Mr. Lipnik.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Colonel Lipnik, if you don't mind.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: ...I was commissioned yesterday in the Army Reserve. Henry Morgenthau arranged it. He's a dear friend.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Congratulations.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Actually it hasn't officially gone through yet. Had wardrobe whip this up. You gotta pull teeth to get anything done in this town. I can understand a little red tape in peacetime, but now it's all-out warfare against the Japs. Little yellow bastards.  They'd love to see me sit this one out.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yes sir, they 

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Anyway, I had Lou read your script for me.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: ...I gotta tell you, Fink. It won't wash.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: With all due respect, sir, I think it's the best work I've done.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Don't gas me, Fink. If you're opinion mattered, then I guess I'd resign and let YOU run the the studio. It doesn't and you won't, and the lunatics are not going to run THIS particular asylum. So let's put a stop to THAT rumor right now.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: I had to call Beery this morning, let him know we were pushing the picture back.  After all I'd told him about quality, about that Barton Fink feeling. How disappointed we were. Wally was heartbroken. The man was devastated. He was  well, I didn't actually call him, Lou did. But that's a fair description, isn't it Lou?
